TITLE: Economic oppression and poor white worker Southern identity during the New South era: A rhetorical analysis of Henry Grady's selected speeches from 1886-1889.
ABSTRACT:
This study situates the constituted rhetorical identity of poor Southern white workers during the New South era. Specifically, this project argues that journalist and politician Henry Grady helped create a mythic image of the poor white Southern worker as both industrious and a victimized hero of the unregulated economic system of American capitalism, while simultaneously constituting a mythic villain of Northern economic and industrial systems.
